title: libphutil: removing bytes from a PhutilRope does not work as intended

profile.name: Phabricator
profile.about: Phabricator is a collection of open source web applications that help software companies build better software.

vulnerability_information_html:
Mongoose. This is a bug in libphutil, it doesn't seem to affect phabricator because the bytes are always removed one buffer at a time. I imagine this could cause security issues in applications made with libphutil as a framework, if they use PhutilRope directly. This is how it goes:

$rope = new PhutilRope();
$rope->append("aaa");
$rope->append("bbb");
$rope->append("ccc");
$rope->append("rrrrddddddddd");
$rope->removeBytesFromHead(4);

echo $rope->getAsString();

should output "bbcccrrrrddddddddd" but will instead output "ddddddddd".

activities.message: Also, the internal length counter of the PhutilRope will be set to a higher value than it should. This could cause an application to be frozen trying to read bytes that are not there.
activities.markdown_message: Also, the internal length counter of the PhutilRope will be set to a higher value than it should. This could cause an application to be frozen trying to read bytes that are not there.

activities.message:
Thanks for the report! This should now be fixed in HEAD:

https://secure.phabricator.com/D14801

Please let me know if I missed anything.

Although this is a good bug report, I don't think it qualifies as a security vulnerability because the security impact is entirely theoretical, and only concrete vulnerabilities are eligible for an award ("vulnerability must significantly compromise the security of a typical Phabricator installation").

(If you can develop a proof of concept that shows how this could impact security on a typical Phabricator installation, I'm happy to award you a bounty retroactively, but I suspect there is no reasonable pathway from this bug to compromising an install.)

activities.message: I believe this is resolved, as the test case now passes and the root implementation error seems straightforward.

activities.message: Per above, this is a good bug report but not a security vulnerability.

activities.message: This can be disclosed at any time, as the fix is already part of the public commit log. Thanks again!

activities.message: The fix seems all right. You're welcome.
